definition: To buy or obtain (an asset or object) for oneself; to learn or develop (a skill, habit, or quality).
mnemonic: Acquire sounds like 'a choir,' where you gather or obtain singers to form a group.
visual_representation: Picture someone receiving a certificate after completing a course, symbolizing acquiring a skill.
example_sentence: He managed to acquire a rare book that had been out of print for decades.

definition: To trouble or threaten persistently; to surround and harass.
mnemonic: Beset sounds like 'be set upon,' indicating being surrounded or attacked.
visual_representation: Imagine someone surrounded by wolves, representing being beset by problems.
example_sentence: The company was beset by financial difficulties, leading to its eventual closure.

definition: Relating to or acting as a cause; implying a cause-and-effect relationship.
mnemonic: Causal sounds like 'cause all,' relating to the cause of something.
visual_representation: Picture a row of dominoes where one causes the next to fall, symbolizing a causal relationship.
example_sentence: The scientist studied the causal relationship between smoking and lung cancer.

definition: Causing harm or damage.
mnemonic: Deleterious sounds like 'delete,' suggesting something harmful that should be deleted or removed.
visual_representation: Picture a toxic chemical being poured into a lake, symbolizing something harmful.
example_sentence: The deleterious effects of pollution on the environment cannot be ignored.

definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
mnemonic: Encomium sounds like 'in come I am,' as if someone is coming in to be praised.
visual_representation: Imagine a person receiving an award with a speech praising their achievements.
example_sentence: The CEO received an encomium for his leadership during the company’s challenging times.

definition: Extremely surprised or shocked.
mnemonic: Flabbergasted sounds like 'gasped,' indicating being so shocked that you gasp.
visual_representation: Picture someone with their mouth wide open in shock, symbolizing being flabbergasted.
example_sentence: She was flabbergasted when she won the lottery.

definition: To provoke or annoy someone so as to stimulate some action or reaction; a spiked stick used for driving cattle.
mnemonic: Goad sounds like 'go at,' as in pushing someone to go at something.
visual_representation: Picture someone poking a bull to make it move forward, symbolizing goading.
example_sentence: He was goaded into action by his friends’ constant teasing.

definition: To use resources economically; to conserve.
mnemonic: Husband as a verb can be remembered as 'husbanding resources,' meaning to manage or conserve them.
visual_representation: Imagine someone carefully rationing food during a long journey, symbolizing conservation.
example_sentence: During the long winter, the family had to husband their supplies carefully to make them last.

definition: To ask someone pressingly and persistently for or to do something.
mnemonic: Importune sounds like 'in poor tune,' where someone keeps asking for something like a broken record.
visual_representation: Picture someone constantly nagging another person for a favor, symbolizing persistent asking.
example_sentence: The beggar importuned passersby for money until someone finally gave him some change.

definition: Furiously angry; dark bluish-gray in color.
mnemonic: Livid sounds like 'live id,' imagining someone furious when their ID doesn’t work.
visual_representation: Picture someone with a red, angry face, almost turning bluish-gray from rage.
example_sentence: She was livid when she found out her brother had borrowed her car without asking.

definition: A deep, persistent sadness; having a feeling of melancholy; sad and pensive.
mnemonic: Melancholy sounds like 'mel-an-chor-lie,' a sad song lying in your heart.
visual_representation: Picture someone sitting alone by a window on a rainy day, looking sad, symbolizing melancholy.
example_sentence: The melancholy music added to the somber mood of the evening.

definition: A person new to or inexperienced in a field or situation.
mnemonic: Novice sounds like 'new vice,' indicating someone new to a habit or skill.
visual_representation: Picture a beginner struggling to learn how to ride a bicycle, symbolizing a novice.
example_sentence: As a novice in cooking, he often burned his meals.

definition: To align or position something relative to a known point or landmark; the countries of Asia, especially East Asia.
hindi_meaning: अभिमुख करना, पूर्वी देशों का समूह
mnemonic: Orient sounds like 'oriented,' meaning to align or position something.
visual_representation: Picture a compass helping someone align their map, symbolizing orientation.
example_sentence: The map was oriented so that north was at the top.

definition: A very poor person.
mnemonic: Pauper sounds like 'poor per,' indicating a person who is very poor.
visual_representation: Picture someone in tattered clothes begging on the street, symbolizing a pauper.
example_sentence: The once-wealthy man died a pauper after losing his fortune.

definition: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous.
mnemonic: Redundant sounds like 're-done,' indicating something that has been done too many times, making it unnecessary.
visual_representation: Picture multiple copies of the same document, with the extras being discarded as unnecessary.
example_sentence: The new bridge made the old ferry service redundant.

definition: Not connected with religious or spiritual matters; worldly.
mnemonic: Secular sounds like 'separate,' indicating something separate from religion.
visual_representation: Picture a government building with a sign that says 'No Religious Affiliation,' symbolizing secularism.
example_sentence: The constitution guarantees a secular state, where religion and government are separate.

definition: Of exceptional strength, size, or power.
mnemonic: Titanic sounds like 'Titanic ship,' which was enormous and powerful.
visual_representation: Imagine a massive ship or structure towering over everything else, symbolizing something titanic.
example_sentence: The company faced a titanic challenge in trying to stay ahead of its competitors.

definition: Not pleasant to taste; difficult to tolerate or accept.
mnemonic: Unpalatable sounds like 'un-palate-able,' indicating something that doesn’t taste good.
visual_representation: Picture someone grimacing after tasting something bitter, symbolizing unpalatability.
example_sentence: The medicine was effective but unpalatable, making it hard to swallow.

definition: A microorganism that can infect and multiply within living cells; a harmful or corrupting influence.
mnemonic: Virus sounds like 'vile us,' something that infects and causes harm.
visual_representation: Imagine a small, spiky ball representing a virus, spreading through a computer or body.
example_sentence: The flu virus spreads quickly in crowded places.

definition: Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
mnemonic: Winsome sounds like 'win some,' indicating someone who wins others over with charm.
visual_representation: Picture a charming child with a bright smile, easily winning everyone’s affection.
example_sentence: Her winsome personality made her popular with everyone she met.
